newsitem.title: USA: Microsoft, Intel mysteriously absent rejigged Dow.
newsitem.headline: Microsoft, Intel mysteriously absent rejigged Dow.

text.p: The absence of Microsoft Corp. and Intel Corp. from the stocks picked to join the newly revised "Dow 30" has left many analysts sceptical of how serious Dow Jones & Co. is about making its blue-chip index more reflective of the American economy.

The most world's most widely tracked stock market barometer replaced four lagging stocks with four new ones to become less smokestack-oriented and more technology-related in a bid to closely represent the economy.

Added to the list were computer maker Hewlett-Packard Corp., health care products company Johnson & Johnson, top U.S. retailer Wal-Mart Stores Inc. and insurance company Travelers Group Inc.. Dropped were Bethlehem Steel Corp., Westinghouse Electric Corp., Texaco Inc. and retailer Woolworth Corp..

"Adding Hewlett-Packard brings the Dow closer to true 'high-tech,' but I would have liked to see more. I'm really waiting for Microsoft," said Bill LeFevre, senior market analyst at Ehrenkrantz King Nussbaum.
Currently, technology is weighted in the 30-stock average through International Business Machines Corp. and United Technologies Corp..

"Hewlett-Packard is a franchise leader. But to exclude Intel and Microsoft? Clearly, that would make the average more representative," said Richard Cripps, chief market strategist at Legg Mason Wood Walker.

A common misconception on Wall Street is that only New York Stock Exchange-listed companies can join Wall Street's most exclusive corporate club, automatically excluding Microsoft and Intel, which are traded on the Nasdaq market.
Not so, according to a Dow Jones spokesman.

Although historically all companies in the Dow have been listed on the NYSE, "being listed on the Nasdaq is not a disqualifying factor at all," said Dow Jones spokesman Roger May. He noted that Nasdaq-listed truck company Yellow Corp. is a component of the Dow Jones Transportation Average.
That makes the absence of Microsoft and Intel even more baffling, market analysts said.

"It really is part of the battle between the Nasdaq and NYSE. I just don't think Microsoft and Intel are serving the public by staying listed on the Nasdaq," said Frank Calta, director of trading at Anvil Institutional Services.
The changes in the Dow, the first such in six years, create more volatility, analysts said.

A move of one-eighth of a point in Dow stocks has been worth about 0.38 of a point change in the index, known as the divisor. With the new change, it will be worth slightly more than 0.40 of a point. Full details about the new divisor will be released on Monday.
"This makes for a much more dangerous Dow," said Harry Laubscher, market analyst for Tucker Anthony. He said that in the shift, three undervalued stocks will be replaced with three overvalued stocks.
"The upshot is the Dow is likely to be hit harder during any major market decines because they lose the undervalued stocks that would provide some support," Laubscher said.

Texaco, reacting to its removal from the prestigious index, said, "It is the privilege of Dow Jones to revise the index. Oil companies are still represented by Exxon and Chevron. We do not see much of an impact; investors will judge us on our performance."
Neither Microsoft nor the Nasdaq could be reached for comment.
